sub_title: Chief Executive Officer at RePuTed Agriculture 4 Development Stichting and Foundation.
summary:
A. ReputedAGRIC4DEV Stichting, legalized by Dutch notary, KvK, and Tax office. It is registered in Ghana and Malawi as a local NGO (Limited by Guarantee). Website: https://reputeda4d.nl/home/ 
    A.1. Board members in The Netherlands: 
    (1) Dr. Putri Ernawati Abidin (voorzitter/leader)
    (2) Prof. Emeritus of K-State Univ, Dr. Edward E. (Ted) Carey (member in NL, vice-Leader out NL)
    (3) Marjolein Ebregt (Secretaris/Secretary board); BA International Studies at Leiden University, The 
          Netherlands (https://www.linkedin.com/in/marjolein-ebregt-62794a51/?originalSubdomain=nl)
    (4) Prof. Emeritus of Wageningen University and Research (WUR), The Netherlands, Dr. Rudy Rabbinge 
          (advisory board) (https://www.wur.nl/en/Persons/Rudy-prof.dr.ir.-R-Rudy-Rabbinge.htm)
    (5) Mr. Maarten Oomes (Financial Director/Penningmeester)

    A.2. Board members in Ghana, in addition to A1 (No 1 to 3) above:
      Mr. Isaac Dorgbetor MSc (Country Director); Mr. Isaac Conduah; Mr. Felix Kamasah

    A.3. Board members in Malawi, in addition to A1 (No 1 to 3) above:
     Mr. W. Kumwenda MSc (Country Director); Mr. W.J. Ndovi; Mr. J. Kazembe; and Mrs. Phelire Nkhoma
       
      
Established partners and Potential Clients:
(1). Private Sector in Ghana, SAYEX (Agri-pay model).
(2). NGOs out of Ghana: YAMPI (Indonesia), Kofi Annan Foundation (AGRA project), etc.
(3). NARES and Relevant Gov Agencies

C. Other Personal experiences:
•	Project leader, manager, supervisor: (1984 – 2018) in Indonesia, Uganda, Malawi, Ghana, Burkina  
        Faso and Nigeria
•	Researcher/program designer based on local knowledge, and applied research (1998 – 2018)
•	Peer Reviewer for international journals (2004 – 2023)
•	Educator/trainer/curriculum development specialty (1978 – 2018)
•	Author for a peer-reviewed journal, books, Information, Education, and Communication 
        (IEC) materials, educational videos, brochures & protocol (1994 – 2023)
•	Project proposal writer and mobilizing potential donors (1984 – 2023)
•	Living and/or working: Indonesia, The Netherlands, Mozambique, Uganda, USA, Malawi, Ghana, 
        Burkina Faso, and Nigeria. Born and with her first career at the Ministry of Agriculture of Indonesia 
        for 12 years, she was an Indonesian nationality. Currently, she is having Netherland nationality 
         and her permanent residence is in The Netherlands.
•	Graduated from Bogor Agricultural University in Indonesia for the first degree as called Ir; and from 
        Wageningen University, The Netherlands for Master and Ph.D. degrees.

treasury_media.title: ERNA ABIDIN AWARD TROPHY - THE MOST INSPIRING ALUMNI IPB UNIVERSITY IN INDONESIA RECEIVED ON 4 OCT 2022 IN BOGOR, INDONESIA
treasury_media.description: I am very grateful to God and IPB University in Indonesia to award me as the most inspiring alumni. The reception was held on 4 Oct 2022 in Bogor, Indonesia. My thanks to Rector IPB University and my niece Puti Draga Rangkuti for the photo and also for representing me at the reception.

treasury_media.title: Portfolio of Partnerships and Projects
treasury_media.description: The first involvement of Reputed Agriculture 4 Development for its mission was supporting and supervising a private sector company, El-Green Agribusiness Limited to get their interest in a commercialisation of sweetpotato planting materials (seeds)....

treasury_media.title: Rooting Out Hunger in Malawi with Nutritious Orange-Fleshed Sweetpotato
treasury_media.description: The ROH in Malawi was on the 4th rank from the selected 50 Harvesting Nutrition project case studies by the World Bank. Harvesting Nutrition was a contest held in 2012 and 2013 organized by this bank to showcase active projects working to improve the impact of agriculture and/or food security on nutrition outcomes. Unfortunately, the NutritionSecure website was out of funds so it has not in the public domain any more. I have a copied pdf of this website but only 1st page is shown here.

treasury_media.title: Putri ABIDIN | Dr. Putri Erna Abidin | Agriculture for Development
treasury_media.description: Putri Erna Abidin is an Agricultural Systems & Nutritional Advocacy Specialist (plant breeding/genetics; agronomy; seed systems, value chains & marketing strategies; applied research for a change & scaling; nutrition, education & adult training...

treasury_media.title: Sweetpotato Multiplication
treasury_media.description: Erna Abidin (Reputed Agriculture for Development Stichting/Foundation) Sweetpotato ( Ipomoea batatas L.) crop is widely grown in tropical, sub-tropical and temperate areas between 40° N and 32° [1][2][3]. Well-drained, light and medium textured soils...

treasury_media.title: Breaking Postharvest.pdf
treasury_media.description: This flyer is Phase I - USAID-OFDA project: Using dry sand to keep sweetpotato roots in large quantity. People believed, a lifespan of storage roots of orange-fleshed sweetpotato was short (~2-3 weeks) but our research revealed, farmers could store roots in a cool dry sand in a sandbox or stepped pit at least up to 7 months in Malawi and 2 months in Ghana. In Phase II of the USAID-OFDA project for scaling, the roots can be stored up to 4 months (see the poster at Wageningen University).

treasury_media.title: FINAL FLYER SWEETPOTATO GREEN LEAFY VEGGIE (NXPowerLite Copy).pdf
treasury_media.description: This is the product from Sweetpotato for Profit and Health Initiative (SPHI), I have written it based on the proof-of-concept projects in Malawi (Rooting out Hunger in Malawi with Nutritious Orange-fleshed Sweetpotato funded by Irish Aid: 1st Oct 2009-31st May 2014); in Ghana, Burkina Faso and Nigeria (Jumpstarting orange-fleshed sweetpotato in West Africa funded by BMGF: 4th April 2014-31st May 2017), and in Northern Malawi and Northern Ghana funded USAID-OFDA: Oct 2013-Apr 2014; SASHA project.

treasury_media.title: 38-SPHI-JUMPSTARTING OFSP IN WEST AFRICA THROUGH DIVERSIFIED MARKETS (NXPowerLite Copy).pdf
treasury_media.description: This is the overall project activities and outcomes of Jumpstarting orange-fleshed in West Africa through diversified markets', funded by Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation (BMGF) from 4th April 2014 to 31st May 2017. The project investigator was Dr. Ted Carey and the project manager was Dr. Erna Abidin (Putri Erna Abidin).

treasury_media.title: 41-SPHI-STRENGTHENING CAPACITY ON OFSP (NXPowerLite Copy).pdf
treasury_media.description: This is one of the project outcomes of 'Jumpstarting orange-fleshed sweetpotato in West Africa through diversified markets", funded by Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation (BMGF) from 4th April 2014 to 31st May 2014. The project investigator was Dr. Ted Carey and the project manager was Dr. Erna Abidin (Putri Erna Abidin).

treasury_media.title: SPHI10-Ghana-Health-Service-Approach (NXPowerLite Copy).pdf
treasury_media.description: This is one of project outcomes of 'Jumpstarting orange-fleshed sweetpotato in West Africa through diversified markets'. Project investigator was Dr. Ted Carey and project manager was Dr. Erna Abidin (Dr. Putri Erna Abidin).

profile_positions.description: A NETHERLANDS-BASED FOUNDATION AND NON-GOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATION, WORKING IN SUSTAINABLE  AGRICULTURE FOR DEVELOPMENT IN THE TROPICS.
profile_positions.title: Foundation Board Leader

profile_positions.location: Based in Wageningen, The Netherlands with working areas in Indonesia and Ghana
profile_positions.description: The scopes of interest are in breeding, crop production systems including seed and germplasm enhancement, value chains and marketing strategies, applied research for a game change & scaling, gender, nutrition, education, and adult training approach. Participatory methods to ensure the relevance of research results to show the impact at scale.
profile_positions.title: Agricultural Systems & Nutritional Advocacy Specialist

profile_positions.description:
1). Managing project funded by Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation: Jumpstarting orange-fleshed sweetpotato in West Africa through diversified markets (Sep 2014 to May 2017). Project areas: Ghana, Burkina Faso and Nigeria.
2). Leading a one-year scaling project funded by USAID-OFDA project: Extending Orange-fleshed Sweetpotato Availability for Vulnerable Households through Good Agricultural Practices and Post-Harvest Storage. Project areas of beneficiaries: Ghana and Burkina Faso
profile_positions.title: Project Manager

profile_positions.description:
I developed a strong partnership between CIP, and relevant government agencies, Department of Agricultural Research Services (DARS), Department of Agricultural Extension Services (DAES), Department of Nutrition, HIV and AIDS (DNHA) in the office of President and Cabinet, International and National NGOs, Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), and Farmers’ organization.

I contributed to build the capacity of partners and farmers by Training of Trainers (ToT) approach, writing up three important syllabi with people in relevant expertise: (i) Sweetpotato production, seed multiplication and crop protection, (ii) Postharvest handling and Triple S for producing vine cuttings, and (iii) OFSP processing.

As Sweetpotato seed system scientist, I developed and modified a seed system specifically for Malawian situation by learning some lessons from Tanzania, Mozambique and the Malawian seed system practices. The 1(‘primary’) -2 (‘secondary’) -3 (‘tertiary’) seed multiplication systems practiced in Malawi fit well with the uni-modal rain distribution pattern and the sweetpotato growing calendar. Thus, we expect that farmers can grow sweetpotato in year around. The 1-2-3 seed systems were defined with implementing partners, where secondary and tertiary at the district level decentralized and managed by farmers under the supervision of the extension from the government and respected NGO. Meanwhile the primary multiplication is at the research station managed by researchers. The secondary and tertiary multiplication are distinctive by the different purpose and multiplication technique. The secondary multiplication mainly produces vines hence a rapid multiplication method is practiced. The tertiary multiplication is for vines and storage roots production with a slight modification from the conventional sweetpotato multiplication. This tertiary multiplication is fitting in the lean months in Malawi where food is scared.
profile_positions.title: Sweetpotato Seed System Scientist and Project Leader for Rooting o
Project leader for the project entitled: Rooting out Hunger in Malawi with nutritious OFSP

company.name: International Potato Center / Centro Internacional de la Papa (CIP)

profile_positions.company: International Potato Center / Centro Internacional de la Papa (CIP)
profile_positions.description:
Achievements:
1). in Malawi (March 2010 - Sep 2014), we have reached more than 190,000 hh beneficiaries from the target of 70,000 hh after 4.5 years of the project funded by Irish Aid in Malawi.
2). In Ghana, Burkina Faso and Nigeria (Sep 2014 - May 2017). Project: Jumpstarting orange-fleshed sweetpotato in West Africa through diversified markets. 117,000 HHS cultivated OFSP in the households (Ghana, Burkina Faso and Nigeria). Through Ghana Health Service program in 22 districts in northern Ghana, ~6,000 pregnant women and lactating mothers were trained on everything about OFSP, ~5,600 received vines and/or roots; from willingness to pay study, out of ~280 interviewed, 16% of women bought the vines or roots. In Burkina Faso, ~40% OFSP found in the 4 sweetpotato big markets in the West of Butkina Faso; before it was 0%. In Nigeria, Osun State, ~1400 schools had OFSP in their students’ meals twice a week. Project was funded by Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation.
3). Northern Malawi (Mzimba & Kasungu) and Northern Ghana (Bawku); period of Oct 2013-Apr 2015, project funded by USAID-OFDA. Results: Sweetpotato roots can be stored fresh in a large quantity in a sand storage: in Malawi, stepped pit is chosen by farmers, predominantly by women, for 7 months; in Ghana, sandbox is the best technology, for 2 months. If we do keep them in a room, the roots can be spoiled at 3 weeks.
4). In Ghana and Burkina Faso (July 2017-Sep 2018). Project: Extending of the sweetpotato roots’ life-span, results: (a) we keep roots in the stepped pit and sand box up to 4 months, using good agricultural practices and sand storage technology in drought-prone areas, funded by USAID-OFDA for scaling the sand storage technology. (b) farmers could manage 28% roots for sprouting as source of planting materials, only 21% were loss instead of 100% normally after 2-3 weeks of being stored in a room, and 51% fresh roots for food in the food stock. Out of 51% fresh roots, 59% roots were at premium quality.
profile_positions.title: Sweetpotato Specialist/Seed System Scientist

profile_positions.description:
-Working as day-to-day management of organic farming under hightunnel and open field condition, student farm practicum together with Johnson County Community College at K-State Horticultural Research and Recreation Center in Olathe, Kansas City, Kansas.
-In one year from Jan 2009 to Jan 2010, the students and growers have learned on how to generate US$ 30,000 from quality organic vegetables from Olathe Station of K-State Univ. We have accounted the revenue to run a small project at the Olathe Station, K-State University. Various markets were structured and this design was in the curriculum of students/growers training. The training was about the extension, communication and education in agriculture including farmers' markets, supermarkets, restaurants and Community Support Agriculture (CSA).
profile_positions.title: Visiting professor
